Award.AwardTitle: Computational and Experimental Investigations of Magnesium Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: This project aims to develop a comprehensive understanding of the effects of alloying elements on the properties of magnesium alloys by integrating first-principles calculations, computational modeling and experimental investigations for the purpose of providing quantitative guidance for designing high performance magnesium alloys. The objectives of the proposed research are severalfold: (a) to predict elastic properties and diffusion behavior of binary and ternary compounds and solution phases through first-principles calculations; (b) to create libraries of diffusion data and elastic properties of important ternary systems through the use of diffusion couples and experiments on individual alloys using advanced analytical tools; (c) to develop models for the properties of magnesium alloys through innovative modeling approaches; (d) to establish mechanistic models that relate elastic properties and diffusivities to the performance of these materials by collaborating with research organizations and companies.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Magnesium is the lightest structural metallic material. This makes magnesium alloys particularly attractive for transportation applications such as automobiles and helicopters for weight reduction and higher fuel efficiency. It is anticipated that the proposed research will contribute to shortening the time to develop new materials and improve existing materials. The participation of underrepresented groups will be encouraged through the SEEMS program (Summer Experience in Earth and Mineral Science) at Penn State for high school students and the recruitment of female students from the Penn State WISER program (Women in Science and Engineering Research). The proposed activity will also educate graduate and undergraduate students in computational and experimental work, encourage students to participate and present their work at meetings of professional societies and foster their writing skills through the preparation of publications for peer-reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnesium (Mg) is the eighth most abundant element in the Earth’s crust and the third most plentiful element dissolved in seawater. It is the lightest structural metallic material with a density of 1.741 g/cm3, in comparison with the densities of Al (2.70 g/cm3) and Fe (7.86 g/cm3). This makes Mg alloys particularly attractive for transportation applications such as automobiles and helicopters for weight reduction and higher fuel efficiency. This project aims to develop a comprehensive understanding of the effects of alloying elements on properties of Mg alloys by integrating first-principles calculations, computational modeling, and experimental investigations and to provide a quantitative guidance for designing high performance Mg alloys. The proposed research project and its achievements build the foundation to answer fundamental questions that can only be addressed efficiently via a combined computational and experimental methodology. For example, what is the best combination of alloying elements in terms of cost and performance and what are the composition and temperature variations for robust processing of magnesium alloys?

In terms of an integrated multi-scale approach to technologically important multi-component Mg alloys, we created considerable knowledge and gained fundamental understandings with respect to Mg and its alloys as shown in our more than 50 publications. For example, our achievements include: (1) diffusion coefficients in Mg and its alloys as detailed in Acta Mater 59 (2011) 3214, Acta Mater 103 (2016) 573, and Acta Mater 109 (2016) 128; (2) methodology to predict temperature-dependent elastic properties (see: J. Phys. Condens. Matter 22 (2010) 375403); (3) thermodynamic database related to Mg-alloys (see: CALPHAD 35 (2011) 191 and CALPHAD 46 (2014) 237); (4) AIMD (ab initio molecular dynamics) understanding of diffusion and structural details (see: Physica B 406 (2011) 3089, J Mater Sci 50 (2015) 1071, and Acta Mater 97 (2015) 75) ; (5) origin of negative thermal expansion in solids (see: Scr. Mater. 65 (2011) 664, Sci. Reports 4 (2014) 7043, and Phys. Rev. B 91 (2015) 024104); (6) electronic localization morphology and defect energies in Mg and its alloys (see: Chem. Phys. Lett. 551 (2012) 121, J. Alloys Compd 586 (2014) 656, Acta Mater 67 (2014) 168, Mater Res Lett 415 (2017) 415, and Phys Rev B 95 (2017) 224106); (7) development of phonon calculations of polar and non-polar materials (see: Computer Phys. Commun. 185 (2014) 2950); and (8) our perspective on Materials Genome (see: Chinese Sci Bulletin 59 (2014) 1619).

In addition to the created knowledge and scientific findings for Mg and its alloys, we also (a) develop open-source software such as YPHON for phonon calculations and ESPEI/pycalphad for thermodynamic modeling and make them web-accessible, see http://pycalphad.org and http://espei.org; (b) publish peer-reviewed papers (49 published, 2 in preparations, and 1 submitted); (c) educate undergraduate and graduate students and postdoc fellows with innovative computational and experimental approaches for PV materials; (d) foster students’ writing and communication skills through publications and conference presentations; (f) participate in activities to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups through the Summer Experience in Earth and Mineral Science (SEEMS) for high school students; (g) recruit female students from the Penn State WISER program (Women in Science and Engineering Research); and (h) incorporate new knowledge on computational and experimental approaches for PV materials into undergraduate and graduate courses.
